folder: Columbus Circle & Broadway & 8th Avenue., Manhattan, NY
text:
(1) Columbus Circle, east side, west from and including Broadway to and including Eighth Ave. This view also shows Eighth Ave, east side, south from and including Columbus Circle, (West 59th Street,) to and including West 58th Street. September 19, 1933. P. L. Sperr.

(2) Columbus Circle, w.59th Street, Broadway and Eighth Avenue, showing where these avenues meet, at the south western corner of Central Park. The statue of Columbus was erected by the Italians resident in America, and presented on the 12th of October, 1892, the fourth centenary of the discovery of America. Copy right 1893. J.S. Johnston and Co. Photographers, New York City.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

folder: Columbus Circle & 8th Avenue (Southwest)., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle (West 59th Street) at the S.W. corner of Eighth Avenue (left).

Across the roofs of these low structures appears a portion of the building at the N.W. corner of 58th Street housing "Reisenweber's, a famous rendezvous.

About 1900

Gift of Urbrock Collection
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - 8th Avenue (Southwest).

folder: Columbus Circle & Broadway & 8th Avenue., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, south side, west from and including Broadway to and including Eighth Ave. Also shown is Broadway, east side, south from but not including West 59th Street, to but not including West 56th Street.  Included is Eight Ave., east side, south from and including Columbus Circle.  The Columbus Monument is seen in the foreground where men are working on excavation for
the I.R.T. Subway.

About 1900.

William B. Parsons Collection.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

Base of Columbus Monument, in the Center of Columbus Circle, at the intersection of Broadway, Eighth Ave, Central Park West and West 59th Street. Foreground shows work in progress for the I.R.T. Subway.

About 1901.

William B. Parsons Collection.

text:
Columbus Circle, south side, west from, but not including W. 59th Street, to and including Eighth Avenue. The view also shows the east side of both Broadway (on the left), and Eighth Avenue (right). Note the Columbus Monument silhouetted by the former Virginia Hotel Building.

About 1905?

New York Edison Company.

folder: 8th Avenue & [59th Street], Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle (W. 59th St.): The Columbus Monument that rises at a Manhattan cross road, and a corner of Central Park. The older view is northward up Central Park South (W. 59th St.). The 2 story structure on the right of the later view is (in 1940) being replaced by a large modern
apartment building.

View 1: 1923
View 2: May 21, 1939

P. L. Sperr

(3)
After demolition of the S.E. corner.

P. L. Sperr
October 9, 1940

folder: Columbus Circle & [Broadway & 8th Avenue & 59th Street.], Manhattan, NY
text:
COLUMBUS CIRCLE, WHERE BROADWAY CROSSES EIGHTH AVE. AT FIFTY-NINTH
ST.
The upper part of Manhattan was laid out more than a hundred years ago upon the gridiron plan. Avenues run north and south and streets run east and west with mathematical and geometrical precision. Practically the only variation from that scheme - north of the "downtown" section - is Broadway, the old post road to Albany, whose slant the city planners found it impossible to change. Broadway intersects at a sharp angle most of the other thoroughfares, thus affording the only vistas in the entire borough and creating what are known as Union Square, Madison Square, Greeley or Herald Square, and Times Square. The picture above shows Broadway at the left and Central Park west, with the Maine
Memorial at the entrance to the park.
1924
Kadel and Herbert
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - [Broadway - 8th Avenue - 59th Street.]

folder: Columbus Circle & Broadway & 8th Avenue., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, south side, west from and including Broadway, to, but not including Eighth Ave. The view also shows Broadway, east side, north from but not including West 55th to West 59th Streets, and also Eighth Ave, east side, north from but not including West 56th Street, to and including Columbus Circle.

About 1924.
Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

folder: Columbus Circle & Central Park South & 59th Street (West) & Broadway & 8th Avenue., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, southeast sector, from Central Park South (West 59th Street), across Broadway to Eighth Ave. (right), as viewed southward from a vantage point on Broadway; above West 60th Street. The 20-story structure shown is the United States Rubber Company Building, No. 1784-1790 Broadway, at the S.E. corner of West 58th Street. Note on the right the excavation for the General Motors Building which will occupy the block bounded by Broadway and Eighth Ave., West 57th to 58th Streets.

About 1924.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - Central Park South - 59th Street (West) - Broadway - 8th Avenue.

folder: 8th Avenue & 59th Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Eighth Avenue at 59th Street, Columbus Circle, showing excavation for Eighth Avenue subway. In the course of constructing the 59th Street station, the Columbus Monument was moved.
About 1927.
Photograph by Ewing Galloway.

folder: Columbus Circle & 59th Street (West) & 8th Avenue., Manhattan, NY
text:
Columbus Circle, south side, west from West 59th Street, to and including Eighth Ave. Also shown is Broadway, east side, south from and including Columbus Circle and Eighth Ave, east side, south from and including Columbus Circle.

About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Columbus Circle - 59th Street (West) - 8th Avenue.

folder: Broadway and 8th Avenue Between West 57th and 59th Streets, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
A general view northward from the General Motors Building (Broadway, west to Eighth Ave. and West 57th north to 58th Streets). This view shows Columbus Circle (foreground), Broadway (left), Central Park West (center), and Central Park (right). Construction work for the Eighth Ave. Subway is shown in two places; on the east side of Central Park West and at the foot of the statue of Christopher Columbus in the center of the Circle. Note the Maine Monument at the Park entrance. Across the top of the view (left), appears the Hudson River, with its Palisades (Jersey shore). About 1932.

Brown Brothers.
title: General view - Broadway - 8th Avenue - North.

folder: Broadway and Columbus Circle and Central Park West, Manhattan, N.Y.
text:
(1)
Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, 1932, No. 1. At Columbus Circle: An alligator balloon, one of those which are regularly de-signed by Tony Sarg, is hovering over the crowd and leering hungrily at some of the spectators. The camera points north on Broadway from Columbus Circle.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 2. Another view; the camera is facing north on Central Park West.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 3. Another view of the alligator.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, No. 1-3.
